items.htmlSnippet:
Three human coronaviruses are known to exist: human coronavirus 229E (HCoV-229E),
HCoV-OC43 and severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS)-associated coronavirus (SARS-
CoV). Here we report the identification of a fourth human coronavirus, HCoV-NL63, using a …

items.htmlTitle: Family cluster of Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus infections, Tunisia, 2013
items.htmlSnippet:
In 2013 in Tunisia, 3 persons in 1 family were infected with Middle East respiratory
syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV). The index case-patient's respiratory tract samples were
negative for MERS-CoV by reverse transcription PCR, but diagnosis was retrospectively …

items.htmlTitle: The genome sequence of the SARS-associated coronavirus
items.htmlSnippet:
We sequenced the 29,751-base genome of the severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS)–
associated coronavirus known as the Tor2 isolate. The genome sequence reveals that this
coronavirus is only moderately related to other known coronaviruses, including two human …

Infectious bronchitis virus (IBV), the coronavirus of the chicken (Gallus gallus), is one of the
foremost causes of economic loss within the poultry industry, affecting the performance of
both meat-type and egg-laying birds. The virus replicates not only in the epithelium of upper …

items.htmlTitle: Characterization and complete genome sequence of a novel coronavirus, coronavirus HKU1, from patients with pneumonia
items.htmlSnippet:

microbiological cause can be identified in a significant proportion of patients. In the past 3

Coronavirus genome replication and transcription take place at cytoplasmic membranes and
involve coordinated processes of both continuous and discontinuous RNA synthesis that are
mediated by the viral replicase, a huge protein complex encoded by the 20-kb replicase …

items.htmlTitle: Commentary: Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV): announcement of the Coronavirus Study Group
items.htmlSnippet:
During the summer of 2012, in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, a hitherto unknown coronavirus (CoV)
was isolated from the sputum of a patient with acute pneumonia and renal failure (1, 2). The
isolate was provisionally called human coronavirus Erasmus Medical Center (EMC)(3) …
